Patch Set 22:

(2 comments)

What goes in the JSON?  Can we have at least a trivial example?

Why would we have made 3 different JSON files?  That seems strange.

PLDM BIOS configuration support was already there(3 json files were already added), My commit just adds support for system specific bios attributes as BIOS attributes may posses different properties for different variants of the same system.

What goes in the JSON?
BIOS Attributes are added to the json file. BIOS attribute represents a specific BIOS parameter or configuration setting. Example would be providing the default OS type for the CEC to boot.

Why would we have made 3 different JSON files
Each BIOS attribute is characterized by a name, type, and type-specific metadata. 
To accommodate the varying metadata associated with different attribute types, separate JSON files are created based on attribute types.

> What goes in the JSON?
> BIOS Attributes are added to the json file. BIOS attribute represents a specific > BIOS parameter or configuration setting. Example would be providing the default OS type for the CEC to boot.

This still doesn't tell me how to create one of these.  There is no sample JSON and no example in the text.
Done
Document BIOS support in PLDM

After the JSON files are parsed, pldm would also create the stringtable, atttribute table, and attributevalue table per spec <link section> in memory , so that we could exchange those tables with remote PLDM terminus using the GET_BIOS_TABLE commands spec <section, link > ?

highlight enabled

@patrick - do you have any more comments on this one ?

This is, frankly, still a poor decision.  Why do we need 3 different files to express these just because they're 3 different attribute types?  You could have just as easily done:

```
{  "integers" : [ ... ],
   ...
}
```

or

```
[ { "type": "integer" ... } ]
```

In the systems like IBM there are nearly 150 BIOS attributes, creating separate files make them easy to maintain. Why do you think this is a poor decision? What advantage do we gain out of making them a single file?

Are we really going to discuss the merits of a per attribute-type file?  It was a lazy / sloppy choice.

> In the systems like IBM there are nearly 150 BIOS attributes, creating separate files make them easy to maintain.

If maintaining 1 file with 150 entries is difficult, maintaining 3 files with 50 entries is not "easy".  In fact, it is clearly *harder* to maintain because you now can't even organize these attributes based on usage patterns.  For example, you probably have 15+ attributes related to DIMM settings; these are now spread across 3 different files in random places in the files, rather than all of them in close proximity to each other.

Why not only allow only 1 attribute per file then?

Hi Patrick , yes what you said also makes sense. Fact is that we don't know why it was architected the way we did long back. We sort of assumed that it was made into 3 different JSON's just for separating various types like interger, string, enum based attributes.

@archana - lets merge all of them together per patrick's suggestion.
Done
How do you express multiple?  Is it expected to a JSON array?
Table 6, 7, and 9 aren't even JSON though....
nit: suggest making this a link [PLDM BIOS Specification] rather than a file-name.
Done

Tables prvides in PLDM BIOS specifacations provides attribute fields based on the attribute type(String/integer/enum). We needed some way to feed the BIOS attributes data to OpenBmc Systems, json config files were added to provide BIOS attributes.
Yes, JSON array is used to provide multiple attributes. I have updated the same in the document.
My point was I have no idea how to connect that sentence ("more info is documented") with the information that immediately follows (after the ":").
Done

nit: This isn't valid JSON because you've added these fields.  It probably would be better to either do these sub-headings outside of the escapes or as json5-style comments (which might require changing ```json to ```json5.
Done
Why are we mixing camelCase and snake_case?
Why do we need "help text"?  Who is the consumer of this?
ACK, we can make all of them in same case. This involves PLDM code changes, so can be taken as separate commit.
The BMC GUI displays the BIOS Attribute Registry to the users. The Attribute details are populated based on redfish schema https://redfish.dmtf.org/schemas/v1/AttributeRegistry.v1_3_8.json.

Can you please document this part then?  How do we generate an AttributeRegistry from PLDM and share that with bmcweb?  I don't see any evidence that this actually happens.  Is this something you have in downstream commits?

How do you combine 3 different attribute files into a single AttributeRegistry?  What is the identifier for the AttributeRegistry?  How do we version it?

How do you handle a multi-host or heterogeneous configuration?  You can have a blade server with two different processor architectures.  There has to be something related to the exact attribute collection that ends up turning into AttributeRegistry identifiers so that external tooling can disambiguate.

Your reference here to AtttributeRegistry makes me think even more is not documented...
+1 , lets have a commit with this fixed below this commit & modify this documentation since its not a big change.

> Can you please document this part then?  How do we generate an AttributeRegistry from PLDM and share that with bmcweb?  I don't see any evidence that this actually happens.  Is this something you have in downstream commits?
> 

PLDM does not generate Attribute registry and share it to bmcweb, PLDM parses these JSON files and fill in the BIOSTable hosted by [bios-settings-mgr daemon](https://github.com/openbmc/bios-settings-mgr) per this [design](https://github.com/openbmc/docs/blob/master/designs/remote-bios-configuration.md#proposed-design) section `BIOS send the data in BIOS configuration PLDM via MCTP`.

The gist is that PLDM daemon parses these JSON files and creates the bios table and sets the [BaseBIOSTable dbus property](https://github.com/openbmc/phosphor-dbus-interfaces/blob/master/yaml/xyz/openbmc_project/BIOSConfig/Manager.interface.yaml#L62) hosted by bios-settings-mgr app. And the per the above design bmcweb is supposed to read data from that property to generate the AttributeRegistry in redfish.

> How do you combine 3 different attribute files into a single AttributeRegistry?  > What is the identifier for the AttributeRegistry?

The `BaseBIOSTable` is a dictionary with variants in it , it can currently handle int64, string and enum values. PLDM post processing all the JSON files, collates all of the interger, string and enum attributes so that it can set the `BaseBIOSTable` property. 

> How do we version it?

I don't think we are supporting versioning as such , but PLDM code is written in such a way that it could handle new attributes being added/removed in the later version of openbmc code base, so it sort of smartly discards its in-memory cache and update them from the JSON file on per attribute basis when we upgrade/downgrade the firmware code levels.

> 
> How do you handle a multi-host or heterogeneous configuration?  You can have a blade server with two different processor architectures.  There has to be something related to the exact attribute collection that ends up turning into AttributeRegistry identifiers so that external tooling can disambiguate.
> 
I don't think PLDM could handle multi-host as of moment. Not just PLDM i don't think we have the Back end bios-settings-mgr app handle multi host scenario(we could probably templatise the bios-settings-mgr) app so that it could host various instances of BaseBIOSTable per host. But I think we might need some infrastructure changes in the BIOS handler to be able to handle BIOS settings per host.

> Your reference here to AtttributeRegistry makes me think even more is not documented...

Agree, we need to add more details.
Done
Done
Display where?

The BMC GUI displays the BIOS Attribute Registry to the users. Redfish schema https://redfish.dmtf.org/schemas/v1/AttributeRegistry.v1_3_8.json talks about DisplayName - "The user-readable display string for the attribute in the defined language."

If these attributes are somehow related to the Redfish AttributeRegistry, let's be very clear about that (by changing the key name).  It seems like these attributes are likely specific to Redfish, so let's use Redfish in the name?  I assume these turn into some specific property in the AttributeRegistry entries, so ideally we use that same name.

Maybe something like this?

```
{
   ...
   "redfish" : { "display_name": ..., "help_text": ... },
   ...
}
```
But patrick , since we only talk to BIOS settings manager and not redfish/bmcweb directly, do you still think it makes sense to add `redfish` key in the JSON files ?
Assuming that we don't need this anymore.

What use do we have for this?  Can't we make them all ASCII or UTF-8?

Shouldn't we specify _exactly_ what we support?  There is no way for us to support a "Vendor Specific" string type, for example.

The PLDM BIOS Specification(https://www.dmtf.org/sites/default/files/standards/documents/DSP0247_1.0.0.pdf) Table7, provides BIOS Attribute table fields for String attribute.
It says
```
StringType
The type of the string. It identifies the character encoding used for this string.
Possible values:
{Unknown=0x00, ASCII=0x01, Hex=0x02, UTF-8=0x03, UTF-16LE=0x04, UTF-16BE=0x05,
Vendor Specific=0xFF} ```
We can set String_type to ASCII for all the string attributes.

Do we actually need to support all of these though?  I don't really care what the specification says; I care about what we're actually implementing.

You still haven't answered what the expected value of the data is after "string_type"...

I dont think PLDM as of today support any other string encoding type apart from ASCII. But having this key here would help people to add support for other encoding types like HEX, UTF-8 in backend ? and use that in the JSON's ? 

or do you want us to remove this key completely and let people figure out and add suppport for this key if they really need any other encoding ?
Lets have the field as is.and people can add support for other types if needed.
You can't do `string.length()` in code?  You need a human to tell you this?

The PLDM BIOS Specification(https://www.dmtf.org/sites/default/files/standards/documents/DSP0247_1.0.0.pdf) Table7, provides BIOS Attribute table fields for String attribute.
```DefaultStringLength:  The length of the default string in bytes. A value of 0 indicates that this attribute has no default
string.```
To handle the possibility of not having the default string value, default string length is used.

How do you have a default string length without a default string value?  I have no idea what you mean by this.

From the spec:

> The length of the default string in bytes. A value of 0 indicates that this attribute has no default string.

Since the spec doesn't use null-terminated strings, this is literally the "string length" of the string payload in the protocol.  I see no reason why this would be in JSON.

+1 agree with you on this.

@archana - lets fix this as well and put the commit below this and fix the documentation as its not a big change.
Done
Seems like you're deriving the type from some of these fields.  Is that the direction you want to go or would you like an explicit "type" field?

I have updated the document by adding "attribute_type". The Attribute type field is already added in json files in commit https://github.com/openbmc/pldm/commit/ac713eec8b97954133fc500056fa394a6d7a7384
We should probably document acceptable values here?
Done
